definitions.definition: used in negative sentences and questions, or sentences with if to mean ‘at any time’

examples.text: Nothing ever happens here.
Don't you ever get tired?
If you're ever in Miami, come and see us.
‘**Have you ever** been to Rome?’ ‘Yes, I have, actually. Not long ago.’
‘Have you ever thought of changing your job?’ ‘No, never/No I haven’t.’
She **hardly ever** *(= almost never)* goes out.
We've **only ever** talked on the phone.
I don't think I ever really thanked you properly.
He wondered whether it would ever actually happen.
We see them very seldom, **if ever**.
I'll **never ever** do that again!
I'm never speaking to you **ever again**!

definitions.definition: used for emphasis when you are comparing things

examples.text: It was raining harder than ever.
Consumers today have more choices than **ever before**.
It's my **best-ever** score.
It's the worst film I've ever seen.

definitions.definition: all the time or every time; always

examples.text: Paul, ever the optimist, agreed to try again.
She married the prince and they **lived happily ever after**.
He said he would love her **for ever (and ever)**.
Their debts grew ever larger *(= kept increasing)*.
the ever-growing problem
an ever-present danger

definitions.definition: used after when, why, etc. to show that you are surprised or shocked

examples.text: Why ever did you agree?

definitions.definition: used to emphasize that somebody does the same thing very often, usually in an annoying way

examples.text: All he ever does is grumble about things.

definitions.definition: used to show that you are surprised or shocked

examples.text: Did you ever hear anything like it?
He's had a car ever since he was 18.
I was bitten by a dog once and I've been afraid of them ever since.
He looks ever so smart.
She's ever such a nice woman.
It's ever so easy.

definitions.definition: used to emphasize that something is certainly true

examples.text: That was a disaster if ever there was one!

definitions.definition: used to emphasize something you are talking about

examples.text: ‘You must have been upset by that.’ ‘Was I ever!’

definitions.definition: sometimes used at the end of an informal letter, before you write your name

wordOrigin: Old English ǣfre, of unknown origin.
